title: November 2024
description: Editor, Prefabs, UI, Signals, Graphics & More
author: antopilo

body.raw: # September ![Thumbnail](https://cdn.antopilo.dev/november/thumbnail.png) Hey everyone! It's been a while, but we're back with a big update, and there's so much to share! This update is packed with features, including improvements to the editor, updates to prefabs, UI enhancements, signals, documentation, graphics, C#, and more! Thereâ€™s a lot to cover, so please bear with me as I try to summarize complex features in a digestible manner. # New Documentation I used to have this old documentation that hasn't been updated in 2 years. We now have this fresh new website that is much nicer to use and maintain. You can access the new documentation in the navbar. ![New documentation website](https://cdn.antopilo.dev/november/doc.png "Doc") # Editor improvements The editor is continuously getting updates. Whether it's new features or UI enhancements, my goal is to keep the editor closely aligned with the engine's API and features. ![The new editor](https://cdn.antopilo.dev/november/editor.png "The new editor") > The new editor The most striking change is the custom title bar, which gives the editor a much more polished and professional appearance. (*yes, this is all done using dear imgui*). # Prefab Editor It was possible to create a prefab from any entity, but it wasnâ€™t possible to edit them without instancing the prefab, and overwriting the previous `.prefab` file. Clunky! Not anymore! You can now open any prefab in its own dedicated editor context, and edit it directly, just like you would with a scene. Plus, when you save your changes, theyâ€™ll automatically propagate to all instances of that prefab in your current scene.

`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:`The UI system is now officially usable! While it\u2019s still in its early stages and I\u2019m not 100% satisfied with it yet, you can now create functional UI elements, and they work as expected. During the implementation, I also took the time to improve, polish, and extend the API with new features.\r
One of the key features is the ability to define custom widgets using C#, HTML, and CSS. Any widgets you define in your C# solution can be used in any HTML file within your projects. While these custom widgets will only update when the DLL is reloaded, so real-time previews aren\u2019t quite there yet, it\u2019s a solid step toward achieving that functionality in the future.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"C:\\Dev\\nuake-website\\content\\blog-source\\_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1bd07d26-6440-4210-ae42-d3aa31635653.mdx",lineNumber:273,columnNumber:1},this),`
